prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request wide bandwidths around our requested lines of HCN (4-3) and HCO+ (4-3) in order to ensure accurate baseline subtraction. Additionally, for the spectral region encompassing HCO+ (4-3) this will ensure optimum chance of detecting the HCN (4-3) v=1 ro-vibrational line, which lies ~0.5 GHz away from the HCO+ (4-3) line.
In the lower sideband, additional spectral windows were added to provide additional coverage of the continuum. One of these windows also covers the CS (7-6) line. However, though the continuum and CS (7-6) are not required for our primary science goals, so detections will provide an added bonus.
The spectral averaging was chosen to maintain reasonable data rates, but we expect to average to approximately 20 km/s resolution for the final data cubes.

We request 0".4 resolution observations in order to isolate any compact nuclear emission from more extended emission of these high density gas tracers. Based on previous observations of similar systems (e.g., Aalto+ 2015), we expect the emission to be centrally concentrated and so not extended on scales larger than ~5".

Our requested RMS was driven by our science goal of detecting or putting limits on emission from the HCN (4-3) v2=1 ro-vibrational transition. We began with our peak HCN (1-0) flux from IRAM 30m single-dish observations (0.03), and scaled these to an expected HCN(4-3) v2=0 flux by assuming (4-3)/(1-0)=4 (in units of Jy km/s). This scaling was based off literature measurements of HCN (4-3) v2=0 and (1-0) for other (U)LIRGs. We then scaled this to the expected v2=1 line flux by assuming a v2=0/v1=1 flux ratio of 10 (in Jy km/s), consistent with existing detections of this v2=1 transition. Finally, we assumed the emission would be spread over 5 beams, a final resolution of 20 km/s channels, and signal-to-noise ratio of 5. The resulting requested RMS is: 5.44mJy. The requested 20 km/s bandwidth will ensure sufficient spectral resolution to differentiate the HCN (4-3) v2=1 line from the HCO+ (4-3), and to analyze the detailed kinematics of the HCN (4-3) and HCO+ (4-3) lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The excitation mechanism of dense gas tracers such as HCN remains an open question in starburst galaxies. Enhanced HCN (relative to CO or HCO+) is often taken as a signpost of active galactic nuclei, but recent results have shown it can also be enhanced in starbursts. Does this enhancemnet have its origin in radiative excitation from a compact starburst? We propose a systematic search for evidence of mid-infrared pumping of the HCN molecule in a sample of nearby luminous infrared galaxies which show a range of global HCN/HCO+ ratios and appear to be staburst dominated, based on their mid-infrared diagnostics. These data will be used to constrain the effect of radiative pumping in enhancing HCN emission via a search for the ro-vibrational HCN (4-3) v=1 line. Additionally, we will simultaneously observe the HCN (4-3) v=0 and HCO+ (4-3) lines to map the spatial distribution of the HCN/HCO+ ratio and constrain the physical conditions of the dense gas.
